context: This can be one of the reasons why the intracellular concentration of DMAPP (100pmol μgChl−1;) is unlikely to reach the levels of DMSP (100nmol μgChl−1  ). Direct comparison of rates of DMAPP and DMSP biosynthesis will reveal the extent of any trade-off between the two metabolites of partial de novo origin (see Outstanding Questions). Some dinoflagellates and haptophytes such as coccolithophores (e.g., Emiliania) are clear exceptions to the ‘either DMS or isoprene’ trend. Some of these organisms possess their own DMSP lyases, and contain the highest reported amounts of intracellular DMSP (∼300mM per cell volume), but also emit isoprene (e.g.,). While an absence of either DMSP lyase or isoprene synthase in some phytoplankton provides a proximate explanation for the ‘either DMS or isoprene’ trend, there must be other equally important functional reasons why evolution took the course that most phytoplankton predominantly emit only one of the two VOCs. Latitudinal Gradients in Oceanic Surface Concentrations and Emissions of DMS and Isoprene Simultaneous measurements of DMS and isoprene emissions from the oceans are scarce. However, we have worldwide data for surface water concentrations of DMS and isoprene (often done separately), and a comparison between the two VOCs offers useful insights.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, Methylsulfanylmethane (DMSP) and isoprene are discussed as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by certain marine phytoplankton. While many phytoplankton predominantly emit either DMSP or isoprene, some species can produce both, indicating a complex evolutionary relationship. The text highlights the significance of these compounds in oceanic emissions and their biosynthesis, suggesting that their coexistence in certain organisms may provide insights into ecological and evolutionary dynamics.
